#Text=Divide Astilbe
#Text=Astilbe are shade-tolerant plants with average moisture needs .
#Text=They have fern-like foliage and colorful flowers ranging from pink to red or white .
#Text=They grow up to tall and they can multiply quickly , so it is important to divide your astilbe regularly .
#Text=Without regular divisions , astilbe may wither from overcrowding .
#Text=Dividing your astilbe is easy , so incorporate this into your gardening practice for beautiful astilbe year after year !
#Text=Steps
#Text=Timing the Astilbe Divisions
#Text=Check every 3 to 4 years .
#Text=Astilbe does not need to be divided every year .
#Text=Plan to divide your astilbe about once every 3 to 4 years or when you notice that it has started to clump up .
#Text=This will help to keep the astilbe healthy and looking its best .
#Text=Plan to divide in the spring .
#Text=Cooler temperatures are best for dividing astilbe , so plan your divisions for the spring .
#Text=Dividing the plants in the summer or when the weather is too warm can be a shock to your plants and may even kill them .
#Text=You may also divide the astilbe in the fall as long as the temperatures are cool .
#Text=Wait until you can get several clumps from the astilbe .
#Text=It is not worth dividing your astilbe if you will only get a few clumps .
#Text=Instead , wait until you can get several clumps from each plant .
#Text=Check the plants to see how many clumps of stems are near the base of the plant .
#Text=For example , if there are only 2 or 3 clumps per plant , then it 's too soon to divide .
#Text=If there are 5 or more clumps , then now is a good time to divide .
#Text=Digging Up the Astilbe
#Text=Water the astilbe a couple of days before dividing .
#Text=Watering helps to soften the soil .
#Text=It will be much easier to divide the astilbe if the soil is moist and softened up a bit .
#Text=Make sure that you water your plants at couple of days before dividing them to ensure that the soil is moist .
#Text=Another option is to plan to divide the astilbe a couple of days after it rains .
#Text=Insert a spade or garden fork deep into the soil under the roots .
#Text=You do not want to cut into the roots , because this can harm the plant .
#Text=Instead , dig down underneath the roots to protect them .
#Text=If you are unsure how deep the roots go , then dig alongside the plant until you find the base of the roots and then dig under them .
#Text=Dig a trench around the root ball .
#Text=Once you have gotten to the bottom of the root ball , use a spade to dig out the soil from around the root ball .
#Text=This will help to loosen the plant and make it easier for you to pull it out of the ground without damaging it .
#Text=Be careful not to harm the root ball as you do this .
#Text=Pull the plant out with the root ball intact .
#Text=Grasp the astilbe near the base of the stems and pull it out of the ground after you have loosened it from the surrounding soil .
#Text=If there is any resistance , use your spade or fork to loosen the dirt some more .
#Text=Do not yank on the astilbe , as this may damage it .
#Text=Shake off the excess dirt .
#Text=Give the plant a good shake as you pull it out to remove the excess dirt from the root ball .
#Text=You may also need to tap or scrape it with your fingers , but be gentle .
#Text=Repeat this process for each of the astilbe plants you want to divide .
#Text=Separating and Replanting the Crowns
#Text=Use your fingers or a pair of garden shears to separate the crowns .
#Text=Once you have removed all of the astilbe plants you want to divide , use your fingers or a pair of gardening shears to break apart the crowns .
#Text=The bases of the astilbe are the crowns , and these are what you need to separate .
#Text=Each crown should only have a few stems extending from it .
#Text=If there is still too much dirt near the base to make out the individual crowns , then rinse away the dirt with some cool water .
#Text=Replant the divisions as soon as possible .
#Text=It is important to get the crowns back into the ground or a pot of soil as soon as possible .
#Text=After you have made the divisions , replant the astilbe in a garden bed or pot of soil with the plants apart .
#Text=Place the root ball deep into the soil so that it is completely covered , and then press the soil around the base of the plant .
#Text=Make sure to locate the plants in light to moderate shade .
#Text=Astilbe does not do well in full sun — too much sun will cause its leaves to burn .
#Text=Avoid areas with poor drainage .
#Text=Astilbe plants need moisture , but too much will cause them to rot .
#Text=Water and add mulch to the soil around the plant to keep it moist .
#Text=Water the astilbe after replanting them to ensure that the soil is moist .
#Text=It is important to keep the plants consistently moist after replanting them , so apply a layer of mulch over the soil as well .
#Text=This will help to keep the moisture in the soil .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Spade
#Text=Fork
#Text=Gardening shears
#Text=Gardening gloves
#Text=Potting soil and pot ( optional )
#Text=Watering can or hose
